18190.text: /When he has leveled its surface,/_does he not scatter dill, sow cumin,/and put in wheat in rows/_and barley in its proper place,/_and emmer as the border?

18191.text: /For he is rightly instructed;/_his God teaches him.

18192.text: ¶Dill is not threshed with a threshing sledge,/_nor is a cart wheel rolled over cumin,/but dill is beaten out with a stick,/_and cumin with a rod.

18193.text: /Does one crush grain for bread?/_No, he does not thresh it forever;/when he drives his cart wheel over it/_with his horses, he does not crush it.

18194.text: /This also comes from the Lord of hosts;/_he is wonderful in counsel/_and excellent in wisdom.

18195.text: §¶Ah, Ariel, Ariel,/_the city where David encamped!/Add year to year;/_let the feasts run their round.

18196.text: /Yet I will distress Ariel,/_and there shall be moaning and lamentation,/_and she shall be to me like an Ariel.

18197.text: /And I will encamp against you all around,/_and will besiege you with towers/_and I will raise siegeworks against you.

18198.text: /And you will be brought low; from the earth you shall speak,/_and from the dust your speech will be bowed down;/your voice shall come from the ground like the voice of a ghost,/_and from the dust your speech shall whisper.

18199.text: ¶But the multitude of your foreign foes shall be like small dust,/_and the multitude of the ruthless like passing chaff./And in an instant, suddenly,

18200.text: /_you will be visited by the Lord of hosts/with thunder and with earthquake and great noise,/_with whirlwind and tempest, and the flame of a devouring fire.

18201.text: /And the multitude of all the nations that fight against Ariel,/_all that fight against her and her stronghold and distress her,/_shall be like a dream, a vision of the night.

18202.text: /As when a hungry man dreams, and behold, he is eating/_and awakes with his hunger not satisfied,/or as when a thirsty man dreams, and behold, he is drinking/_and awakes faint, with his thirst not quenched,/so shall the multitude of all the nations be/_that fight against Mount Zion.

18203.text: ¶Astonish yourselves and be astonished;/_blind yourselves and be blind!/Be drunk, but not with wine;/_stagger, but not with strong drink!

18204.text: /For the Lord has poured out upon you/_a spirit of deep sleep,/and has closed your eyes (the prophets),/_and covered your heads (the seers).

18205.text: ¶And the vision of all this has become to you like the words of a book that is sealed. When men give it to one who can read, saying, “Read this,” he says, “I cannot, for it is sealed.”

18206.text: And when they give the book to one who cannot read, saying, “Read this,” he says, “I cannot read.”

18207.text: ¶And the Lord said:/“Because this people draw near with their mouth/_and honor me with their lips,/_while their hearts are far from me,/and their fear of me is a commandment taught by men,

18208.text: /therefore, behold, I will again/_do wonderful things with this people,/_with wonder upon wonder;/and the wisdom of their wise men shall perish,/_and the discernment of their discerning men shall be hidden.”

18209.text: ¶Ah, you who hide deep from the Lord your counsel,/_whose deeds are in the dark,/_and who say, “Who sees us? Who knows us?”

18210.text: /You turn things upside down!/Shall the potter be regarded as the clay,/that the thing made should say of its maker,/_“He did not make me”;/or the thing formed say of him who formed it,/_“He has no understanding”?

18211.text: ¶Is it not yet a very little while/_until Lebanon shall be turned into a fruitful field,/_and the fruitful field shall be regarded as a forest?

18212.text: /In that day the deaf shall hear/_the words of a book,/and out of their gloom and darkness/_the eyes of the blind shall see.

18213.text: /The meek shall obtain fresh joy in the Lord,/_and the poor among mankind shall exult in the Holy One of Israel.

18214.text: /For the ruthless shall come to nothing/_and the scoffer cease,/_and all who watch to do evil shall be cut off,

18215.text: /who by a word make a man out to be an offender,/_and lay a snare for him who reproves in the gate,/_and with an empty plea turn aside him who is in the right.

18216.text: ¶Therefore thus says the Lord, who redeemed Abraham, concerning the house of Jacob:¶▼“Jacob shall no more be ashamed,/_no more shall his face grow pale.

18217.text: /For when he sees his children,/_the work of my hands, in his midst,/_they will sanctify my name;/they will sanctify the Holy One of Jacob/_and will stand in awe of the God of Israel.

18218.text: /And those who go astray in spirit will come to understanding,/_and those who murmur will accept instruction.”

18219.text: §¶“Ah, stubborn children,” declares the Lord,/“who carry out a plan, but not mine,/and who make an alliance, but not of my Spirit,/_that they may add sin to sin;

18220.text: /who set out to go down to Egypt,/_without asking for my direction,/to take refuge in the protection of Pharaoh/_and to seek shelter in the shadow of Egypt!

18221.text: /Therefore shall the protection of Pharaoh turn to your shame,/_and the shelter in the shadow of Egypt to your humiliation.

18222.text: /For though his officials are at Zoan/_and his envoys reach Hanes,

18223.text: /everyone comes to shame/_through a people that cannot profit them,/that brings neither help nor profit,/_but shame and disgrace.”

18224.text: ¶An oracle on the beasts of the Negeb.¶▼Through a land of trouble and anguish,/_from where come the lioness and the lion,/_the adder and the flying fiery serpent,/they carry their riches on the backs of donkeys,/_and their treasures on the humps of camels,/_to a people that cannot profit them.

18225.text: /Egypt’s help is worthless and empty;/_therefore I have called her/_“Rahab who sits still.”

18226.text: §¶And now, go, write it before them on a tablet/_and inscribe it in a book,/that it may be for the time to come/_as a witness forever.

18227.text: /For they are a rebellious people,/_lying children,/children unwilling to hear/_the instruction of the Lord;

18228.text: /who say to the seers, “Do not see,”/_and to the prophets, “Do not prophesy to us what is right;/speak to us smooth things,/_prophesy illusions,

18229.text: /leave the way, turn aside from the path,/_let us hear no more about the Holy One of Israel.”

18230.text: /Therefore thus says the Holy One of Israel,/“Because you despise this word/_and trust in oppression and perverseness/_and rely on them,

18231.text: /therefore this iniquity shall be to you/_like a breach in a high wall, bulging out, and about to collapse,/_whose breaking comes suddenly, in an instant;

18232.text: /and its breaking is like that of a potter’s vessel/_that is smashed so ruthlessly/that among its fragments not a shard is found/_with which to take fire from the hearth,/_or to dip up water out of the cistern.”

18233.text: ¶For thus said the Lord God, the Holy One of Israel,/“In returning and rest you shall be saved;/_in quietness and in trust shall be your strength.”/But you were unwilling,

18234.text: /and you said,/“No! We will flee upon horses”;/_therefore you shall flee away;/and, “We will ride upon swift steeds”;/_therefore your pursuers shall be swift.

18235.text: /A thousand shall flee at the threat of one;/_at the threat of five you shall flee,/till you are left/_like a flagstaff on the top of a mountain,/_like a signal on a hill.

18236.text: §¶Therefore the Lord waits to be gracious to you,/_and therefore he exalts himself to show mercy to you./For the Lord is a God of justice;/_blessed are all those who wait for him.

18237.text: ¶For a people shall dwell in Zion, in Jerusalem; you shall weep no more. He will surely be gracious to you at the sound of your cry. As soon as he hears it, he answers you.

18238.text: And though the Lord give you the bread of adversity and the water of affliction, yet your Teacher will not hide himself anymore, but your eyes shall see your Teacher.

18239.text: And your ears shall hear a word behind you, saying, “This is the way, walk in it,” when you turn to the right or when you turn to the left.

18240.text: Then you will defile your carved idols overlaid with silver and your gold‐plated metal images. You will scatter them as unclean things. You will say to them, “Be gone!”

18241.text: ¶And he will give rain for the seed with which you sow the ground, and bread, the produce of the ground, which will be rich and plenteous. In that day your livestock will graze in large pastures,

18242.text: and the oxen and the donkeys that work the ground will eat seasoned fodder, which has been winnowed with shovel and fork.

18243.text: And on every lofty mountain and every high hill there will be brooks running with water, in the day of the great slaughter, when the towers fall.

18244.text: Moreover, the light of the moon will be as the light of the sun, and the light of the sun will be sevenfold, as the light of seven days, in the day when the Lord binds up the brokenness of his people, and heals the wounds inflicted by his blow.

18245.text: ¶Behold, the name of the Lord comes from afar,/_burning with his anger, and in thick rising smoke;/his lips are full of fury,/_and his tongue is like a devouring fire;

18246.text: /his breath is like an overflowing stream/_that reaches up to the neck;/to sift the nations with the sieve of destruction,/_and to place on the jaws of the peoples a bridle that leads astray.

18247.text: ¶You shall have a song as in the night when a holy feast is kept, and gladness of heart, as when one sets out to the sound of the flute to go to the mountain of the Lord, to the Rock of Israel.

18248.text: And the Lord will cause his majestic voice to be heard and the descending blow of his arm to be seen, in furious anger and a flame of devouring fire, with a cloudburst and storm and hailstones.

18249.text: The Assyrians will be terror‐stricken at the voice of the Lord, when he strikes with his rod.

18250.text: And every stroke of the appointed staff that the Lord lays on them will be to the sound of tambourines and lyres. Battling with brandished arm, he will fight with them.

18251.text: For a burning place has long been prepared; indeed, for the king it is made ready, its pyre made deep and wide, with fire and wood in abundance; the breath of the Lord, like a stream of sulfur, kindles it.

18252.text: §¶Woe to those who go down to Egypt for help/_and rely on horses,/who trust in chariots because they are many/_and in horsemen because they are very strong,/but do not look to the Holy One of Israel/_or consult the Lord!

18253.text: /And yet he is wise and brings disaster;/_he does not call back his words,/but will arise against the house of the evildoers/_and against the helpers of those who work iniquity.

18254.text: /The Egyptians are man, and not God,/_and their horses are flesh, and not spirit./When the Lord stretches out his hand,/_the helper will stumble, and he who is helped will fall,/_and they will all perish together.

18255.text: ¶For thus the Lord said to me,/“As a lion or a young lion growls over his prey,/_and when a band of shepherds is called out against him/he is not terrified by their shouting/_or daunted at their noise,/so the Lord of hosts will come down/_to fight on Mount Zion and on its hill.

18256.text: /Like birds hovering, so the Lord of hosts/_will protect Jerusalem;/he will protect and deliver it;/_he will spare and rescue it.”

18257.text: ¶Turn to him from whom people have deeply revolted, O children of Israel.

18258.text: For in that day everyone shall cast away his idols of silver and his idols of gold, which your hands have sinfully made for you.

18259.text: ¶“And the Assyrian shall fall by a sword, not of man;/_and a sword, not of man, shall devour him;/and he shall flee from the sword,/_and his young men shall be put to forced labor.

18260.text: /His rock shall pass away in terror,/_and his officers desert the standard in panic,”/declares the Lord, whose fire is in Zion,/_and whose furnace is in Jerusalem.

18261.text: §¶Behold, a king will reign in righteousness,/_and princes will rule in justice.

18262.text: /Each will be like a hiding place from the wind,/_a shelter from the storm,/like streams of water in a dry place,/_like the shade of a great rock in a weary land.

18263.text: /Then the eyes of those who see will not be closed,/_and the ears of those who hear will give attention.

18264.text: /The heart of the hasty will understand and know,/_and the tongue of the stammerers will hasten to speak distinctly.

18265.text: /The fool will no more be called noble,/_nor the scoundrel said to be honorable.

18266.text: /For the fool speaks folly,/_and his heart is busy with iniquity,/to practice ungodliness,/_to utter error concerning the Lord,/to leave the craving of the hungry unsatisfied,/_and to deprive the thirsty of drink.

18267.text: /As for the scoundrel—his devices are evil;/_he plans wicked schemes/to ruin the poor with lying words,/_even when the plea of the needy is right.

18268.text: /But he who is noble plans noble things,/_and on noble things he stands.

18269.text: §¶Rise up, you women who are at ease, hear my voice;/_you complacent daughters, give ear to my speech.

18270.text: /In little more than a year/_you will shudder, you complacent women;/for the grape harvest fails,/_the fruit harvest will not come.

18271.text: /Tremble, you women who are at ease,/_shudder, you complacent ones;/strip, and make yourselves bare,/_and tie sackcloth around your waist.

18272.text: /Beat your breasts for the pleasant fields,/_for the fruitful vine,

18273.text: /for the soil of my people/_growing up in thorns and briers,/yes, for all the joyous houses/_in the exultant city.

18274.text: /For the palace is forsaken,/_the populous city deserted;/the hill and the watchtower/_will become dens forever,/a joy of wild donkeys,/_a pasture of flocks;

18275.text: /until the Spirit is poured upon us from on high,/_and the wilderness becomes a fruitful field,/_and the fruitful field is deemed a forest.

18276.text: /Then justice will dwell in the wilderness,/_and righteousness abide in the fruitful field.

18277.text: /And the effect of righteousness will be peace,/_and the result of righteousness, quietness and trust forever.

18278.text: /My people will abide in a peaceful habitation,/_in secure dwellings, and in quiet resting places.

18279.text: /And it will hail when the forest falls down,/_and the city will be utterly laid low.

18280.text: /Happy are you who sow beside all waters,/_who let the feet of the ox and the donkey range free.

18281.text: §¶Ah, you destroyer,/_who yourself have not been destroyed,/you traitor,/_whom none has betrayed!/When you have ceased to destroy,/_you will be destroyed;/and when you have finished betraying,/_they will betray you.

18282.text: ¶O Lord, be gracious to us; we wait for you./_Be our arm every morning,/_our salvation in the time of trouble.

18283.text: /At the tumultuous noise peoples flee;/_when you lift yourself up, nations are scattered,

18284.text: /and your spoil is gathered as the caterpillar gathers;/_as locusts leap, it is leapt upon.

18285.text: ¶The Lord is exalted, for he dwells on high;/_he will fill Zion with justice and righteousness,

18286.text: /and he will be the stability of your times,/_abundance of salvation, wisdom, and knowledge;/_the fear of the Lord is Zion’s treasure.

18287.text: ¶Behold, their heroes cry in the streets;/_the envoys of peace weep bitterly.

18288.text: /The highways lie waste;/_the traveler ceases./Covenants are broken;/_cities are despised;/_there is no regard for man.

18289.text: /The land mourns and languishes;/_Lebanon is confounded and withers away;/Sharon is like a desert,/_and Bashan and Carmel shake off their leaves.

18290.text: ¶“Now I will arise,” says the Lord,/_“now I will lift myself up;/_now I will be exalted.

18291.text: /You conceive chaff; you give birth to stubble;/_your breath is a fire that will consume you.

18292.text: /And the peoples will be as if burned to lime,/_like thorns cut down, that are burned in the fire.”

18293.text: ¶Hear, you who are far off, what I have done;/_and you who are near, acknowledge my might.

18294.text: /The sinners in Zion are afraid;/_trembling has seized the godless:/“Who among us can dwell with the consuming fire?/_Who among us can dwell with everlasting burnings?”

18295.text: /He who walks righteously and speaks uprightly,/_who despises the gain of oppressions,/who shakes his hands, lest they hold a bribe,/_who stops his ears from hearing of bloodshed/_and shuts his eyes from looking on evil,

18296.text: /he will dwell on the heights;/_his place of defense will be the fortresses of rocks;/_his bread will be given him; his water will be sure.

18297.text: ¶Your eyes will behold the king in his beauty;/_they will see a land that stretches afar.

18298.text: /Your heart will muse on the terror:/_“Where is he who counted, where is he who weighed the tribute?/_Where is he who counted the towers?”

18299.text: /You will see no more the insolent people,/_the people of an obscure speech that you cannot comprehend,/_stammering in a tongue that you cannot understand.

18300.text: /Behold Zion, the city of our appointed feasts!/_Your eyes will see Jerusalem,/_an untroubled habitation, an immovable tent,/whose stakes will never be plucked up,/_nor will any of its cords be broken.

18301.text: /But there the Lord in majesty will be for us/_a place of broad rivers and streams,/where no galley with oars can go,/_nor majestic ship can pass.

18302.text: /For the Lord is our judge; the Lord is our lawgiver;/_the Lord is our king; he will save us.

18303.text: ¶Your cords hang loose;/_they cannot hold the mast firm in its place/_or keep the sail spread out./Then prey and spoil in abundance will be divided;/_even the lame will take the prey.

18304.text: /And no inhabitant will say, “I am sick”;/_the people who dwell there will be forgiven their iniquity.

18305.text: §¶Draw near, O nations, to hear,/_and give attention, O peoples!/Let the earth hear, and all that fills it;/_the world, and all that comes from it.

18306.text: /For the Lord is enraged against all the nations,/_and furious against all their host;/_he has devoted them to destruction, has given them over for slaughter.

18307.text: /Their slain shall be cast out,/_and the stench of their corpses shall rise;/_the mountains shall flow with their blood.

18308.text: /All the host of heaven shall rot away,/_and the skies roll up like a scroll./All their host shall fall,/_as leaves fall from the vine,/_like leaves falling from the fig tree.

18309.text: ¶For my sword has drunk its fill in the heavens;/_behold, it descends for judgment upon Edom,/_upon the people I have devoted to destruction.

18310.text: /The Lord has a sword; it is sated with blood;/_it is gorged with fat,/_with the blood of lambs and goats,/_with the fat of the kidneys of rams./For the Lord has a sacrifice in Bozrah,/_a great slaughter in the land of Edom.

18311.text: /Wild oxen shall fall with them,/_and young steers with the mighty bulls./Their land shall drink its fill of blood,/_and their soil shall be gorged with fat.

18312.text: ¶For the Lord has a day of vengeance,/_a year of recompense for the cause of Zion.

18313.text: /And the streams of Edom shall be turned into pitch,/_and her soil into sulfur;/_her land shall become burning pitch.

18314.text: /Night and day it shall not be quenched;/_its smoke shall go up forever./From generation to generation it shall lie waste;/_none shall pass through it forever and ever.

18315.text: /But the hawk and the porcupine shall possess it,/_the owl and the raven shall dwell in it./He shall stretch the line of confusion over it,/_and the plumb line of emptiness.

18316.text: /Its nobles—there is no one there to call it a kingdom,/_and all its princes shall be nothing.

18317.text: ¶Thorns shall grow over its strongholds,/_nettles and thistles in its fortresses./It shall be the haunt of jackals,/_an abode for ostriches.

18318.text: /And wild animals shall meet with hyenas;/_the wild goat shall cry to his fellow;/indeed, there the night bird settles/_and finds for herself a resting place.

18319.text: ¶There the owl nests and lays/_and hatches and gathers her young in her shadow;/indeed, there the hawks are gathered,/_each one with her mate.

18320.text: /Seek and read from the book of the Lord:/_Not one of these shall be missing;/_none shall be without her mate./For the mouth of the Lord has commanded,/_and his Spirit has gathered them.

18321.text: /He has cast the lot for them;/_his hand has portioned it out to them with the line;/they shall possess it forever;/_from generation to generation they shall dwell in it.

18322.text: §¶The wilderness and the dry land shall be glad;/_the desert shall rejoice and blossom like the crocus;

18323.text: /it shall blossom abundantly/_and rejoice with joy and singing./The glory of Lebanon shall be given to it,/_the majesty of Carmel and Sharon./They shall see the glory of the Lord,/_the majesty of our God.

18324.text: ¶Strengthen the weak hands,/_and make firm the feeble knees.

18325.text: /Say to those who have an anxious heart,/_“Be strong; fear not!/Behold, your God/_will come with vengeance,/with the recompense of God./_He will come and save you.”

18326.text: ¶Then the eyes of the blind shall be opened,/_and the ears of the deaf unstopped;

18327.text: /then shall the lame man leap like a deer,/_and the tongue of the mute sing for joy./For waters break forth in the wilderness,/_and streams in the desert;

18328.text: /the burning sand shall become a pool,/_and the thirsty ground springs of water;/in the haunt of jackals, where they lie down,/_the grass shall become reeds and rushes.

18329.text: ¶And a highway shall be there,/_and it shall be called the Way of Holiness;/the unclean shall not pass over it./_It shall belong to those who walk on the way;/_even if they are fools, they shall not go astray.

18330.text: /No lion shall be there,/_nor shall any ravenous beast come up on it;/they shall not be found there,/_but the redeemed shall walk there.

18331.text: /And the ransomed of the Lord shall return/_and come to Zion with singing;/everlasting joy shall be upon their heads;/_they shall obtain gladness and joy,/_and sorrow and sighing shall flee away.

18332.text: §¶In the fourteenth year of King Hezekiah, Sennacherib king of Assyria came up against all the fortified cities of Judah and took them.

18333.text: And the king of Assyria sent the Rabshakeh from Lachish to King Hezekiah at Jerusalem, with a great army. And he stood by the conduit of the upper pool on the highway to the Washer’s Field.

18334.text: And there came out to him Eliakim the son of Hilkiah, who was over the household, and Shebna the secretary, and Joah the son of Asaph, the recorder.

18335.text: ¶And the Rabshakeh said to them, “Say to Hezekiah, ‘Thus says the great king, the king of Assyria: On what do you rest this trust of yours?

18336.text: Do you think that mere words are strategy and power for war? In whom do you now trust, that you have rebelled against me?

18337.text: Behold, you are trusting in Egypt, that broken reed of a staff, which will pierce the hand of any man who leans on it. Such is Pharaoh king of Egypt to all who trust in him.

18338.text: But if you say to me, “We trust in the Lord our God,” is it not he whose high places and altars Hezekiah has removed, saying to Judah and to Jerusalem, “You shall worship before this altar”?

18339.text: Come now, make a wager with my master the king of Assyria: I will give you two thousand horses, if you are able on your part to set riders on them.

18340.text: How then can you repulse a single captain among the least of my master’s servants, when you trust in Egypt for chariots and for horsemen?

18341.text: Moreover, is it without the Lord that I have come up against this land to destroy it? The Lord said to me, Go up against this land and destroy it.’”

18342.text: ¶Then Eliakim, Shebna, and Joah said to the Rabshakeh, “Please speak to your servants in Aramaic, for we understand it. Do not speak to us in the language of Judah within the hearing of the people who are on the wall.”

18343.text: But the Rabshakeh said, “Has my master sent me to speak these words to your master and to you, and not to the men sitting on the wall, who are doomed with you to eat their own dung and drink their own urine?”

18344.text: ¶Then the Rabshakeh stood and called out in a loud voice in the language of Judah: “Hear the words of the great king, the king of Assyria!

18345.text: Thus says the king: ‘Do not let Hezekiah deceive you, for he will not be able to deliver you.

18346.text: Do not let Hezekiah make you trust in the Lord by saying, “The Lord will surely deliver us. This city will not be given into the hand of the king of Assyria.”

18347.text: Do not listen to Hezekiah. For thus says the king of Assyria: Make your peace with me and come out to me. Then each one of you will eat of his own vine, and each one of his own fig tree, and each one of you will drink the water of his own cistern,

18348.text: until I come and take you away to a land like your own land, a land of grain and wine, a land of bread and vineyards.

18349.text: Beware lest Hezekiah mislead you by saying, “The Lord will deliver us.” Has any of the gods of the nations delivered his land out of the hand of the king of Assyria?

18350.text: Where are the gods of Hamath and Arpad? Where are the gods of Sepharvaim? Have they delivered Samaria out of my hand?

18351.text: Who among all the gods of these lands have delivered their lands out of my hand, that the Lord should deliver Jerusalem out of my hand?’”

18352.text: ¶But they were silent and answered him not a word, for the king’s command was, “Do not answer him.”

18353.text: Then Eliakim the son of Hilkiah, who was over the household, and Shebna the secretary, and Joah the son of Asaph, the recorder, came to Hezekiah with their clothes torn, and told him the words of the Rabshakeh.

18354.text: §¶As soon as King Hezekiah heard it, he tore his clothes and covered himself with sackcloth and went into the house of the Lord.

18355.text: And he sent Eliakim, who was over the household, and Shebna the secretary, and the senior priests, covered with sackcloth, to the prophet Isaiah the son of Amoz.

18356.text: They said to him, “Thus says Hezekiah, ‘This day is a day of distress, of rebuke, and of disgrace; children have come to the point of birth, and there is no strength to bring them forth.

18357.text: It may be that the Lord your God will hear the words of the Rabshakeh, whom his master the king of Assyria has sent to mock the living God, and will rebuke the words that the Lord your God has heard; therefore lift up your prayer for the remnant that is left.’”

18358.text: ¶When the servants of King Hezekiah came to Isaiah,

18359.text: Isaiah said to them, “Say to your master, ‘Thus says the Lord: Do not be afraid because of the words that you have heard, with which the young men of the king of Assyria have reviled me.

18360.text: Behold, I will put a spirit in him, so that he shall hear a rumor and return to his own land, and I will make him fall by the sword in his own land.’”

18361.text: ¶The Rabshakeh returned, and found the king of Assyria fighting against Libnah, for he had heard that the king had left Lachish.

18362.text: Now the king heard concerning Tirhakah king of Cush, “He has set out to fight against you.” And when he heard it, he sent messengers to Hezekiah, saying,

18363.text: “Thus shall you speak to Hezekiah king of Judah: ‘Do not let your God in whom you trust deceive you by promising that Jerusalem will not be given into the hand of the king of Assyria.

18364.text: Behold, you have heard what the kings of Assyria have done to all lands, devoting them to destruction. And shall you be delivered?

18365.text: Have the gods of the nations delivered them, the nations that my fathers destroyed, Gozan, Haran, Rezeph, and the people of Eden who were in Telassar?

18366.text: Where is the king of Hamath, the king of Arpad, the king of the city of Sepharvaim, the king of Hena, or the king of Ivvah?’”

18367.text: §¶Hezekiah received the letter from the hand of the messengers, and read it; and Hezekiah went up to the house of the Lord, and spread it before the Lord.

18368.text: And Hezekiah prayed to the Lord:

18369.text: “O Lord of hosts, God of Israel, enthroned above the cherubim, you are the God, you alone, of all the kingdoms of the earth; you have made heaven and earth.

18370.text: Incline your ear, O Lord, and hear; open your eyes, O Lord, and see; and hear all the words of Sennacherib, which he has sent to mock the living God.

18371.text: Truly, O Lord, the kings of Assyria have laid waste all the nations and their lands,

18372.text: and have cast their gods into the fire. For they were no gods, but the work of men’s hands, wood and stone. Therefore they were destroyed.

18373.text: So now, O Lord our God, save us from his hand, that all the kingdoms of the earth may know that you alone are the Lord.”

18374.text: §¶Then Isaiah the son of Amoz sent to Hezekiah, saying, “Thus says the Lord, the God of Israel: Because you have prayed to me concerning Sennacherib king of Assyria,

18375.text: this is the word that the Lord has spoken concerning him:¶▼“‘She despises you, she scorns you—/_the virgin daughter of Zion;/she wags her head behind you—/_the daughter of Jerusalem.

18376.text: ¶“‘Whom have you mocked and reviled?/_Against whom have you raised your voice/and lifted your eyes to the heights?/_Against the Holy One of Israel!

18377.text: /By your servants you have mocked the Lord,/_and you have said, With my many chariots/I have gone up the heights of the mountains,/_to the far recesses of Lebanon,/to cut down its tallest cedars,/_its choicest cypresses,/to come to its remotest height,/_its most fruitful forest.

18378.text: /I dug wells/_and drank waters,/to dry up with the sole of my foot/_all the streams of Egypt.

18379.text: ¶“‘Have you not heard/_that I determined it long ago?/I planned from days of old/_what now I bring to pass,/that you should make fortified cities/_crash into heaps of ruins,

18380.text: /while their inhabitants, shorn of strength,/_are dismayed and confounded,/and have become like plants of the field/_and like tender grass,/like grass on the housetops,/_blighted before it is grown.

18381.text: ¶“‘I know your sitting down/_and your going out and coming in,/_and your raging against me.

18382.text: /Because you have raged against me/_and your complacency has come to my ears,/I will put my hook in your nose/_and my bit in your mouth,/and I will turn you back on the way/_by which you came.’

18383.text: ¶“And this shall be the sign for you: this year you shall eat what grows of itself, and in the second year what springs from that. Then in the third year sow and reap, and plant vineyards, and eat their fruit.

18384.text: And the surviving remnant of the house of Judah shall again take root downward and bear fruit upward.

18385.text: For out of Jerusalem shall go a remnant, and out of Mount Zion a band of survivors. The zeal of the Lord of hosts will do this.

18386.text: ¶“Therefore thus says the Lord concerning the king of Assyria: He shall not come into this city or shoot an arrow there or come before it with a shield or cast up a siege mound against it.

18387.text: By the way that he came, by the same he shall return, and he shall not come into this city, declares the Lord.

18388.text: For I will defend this city to save it, for my own sake and for the sake of my servant David.”

18389.text: ¶And the angel of the Lord went out and struck down 185,000 in the camp of the Assyrians. And when people arose early in the morning, behold, these were all dead bodies.

18390.text: Then Sennacherib king of Assyria departed and returned home and lived at Nineveh.

18391.text: And as he was worshiping in the house of Nisroch his god, Adrammelech and Sharezer, his sons, struck him down with the sword. And after they escaped into the land of Ararat, Esarhaddon his son reigned in his place.

18392.text: §¶In those days Hezekiah became sick and was at the point of death. And Isaiah the prophet the son of Amoz came to him, and said to him, “Thus says the Lord: Set your house in order, for you shall die, you shall not recover.”

18393.text: Then Hezekiah turned his face to the wall and prayed to the Lord,

18394.text: and said, “Please, O Lord, remember how I have walked before you in faithfulness and with a whole heart, and have done what is good in your sight.” And Hezekiah wept bitterly.

18395.text: ¶Then the word of the Lord came to Isaiah:

18396.text: “Go and say to Hezekiah, Thus says the Lord, the God of David your father: I have heard your prayer; I have seen your tears. Behold, I will add fifteen years to your life.

18397.text: I will deliver you and this city out of the hand of the king of Assyria, and will defend this city.

18398.text: ¶“This shall be the sign to you from the Lord, that the Lord will do this thing that he has promised:

18399.text: Behold, I will make the shadow cast by the declining sun on the dial of Ahaz turn back ten steps.” So the sun turned back on the dial the ten steps by which it had declined.

18400.text: ¶A writing of Hezekiah king of Judah, after he had been sick and had recovered from his sickness:

18401.text: ¶I said, In the middle of my days/_I must depart;/I am consigned to the gates of Sheol/_for the rest of my years.

18402.text: /I said, I shall not see the Lord,/_the Lord in the land of the living;/I shall look on man no more/_among the inhabitants of the world.

18403.text: /My dwelling is plucked up and removed from me/_like a shepherd’s tent;/like a weaver I have rolled up my life;/_he cuts me off from the loom;/from day to night you bring me to an end;

18404.text: /_I calmed myself until morning;/like a lion he breaks all my bones;/_from day to night you bring me to an end.

18405.text: ¶Like a swallow or a crane I chirp;/_I moan like a dove./My eyes are weary with looking upward./_O Lord, I am oppressed; be my pledge of safety!

18406.text: /What shall I say? For he has spoken to me,/_and he himself has done it./I walk slowly all my years/_because of the bitterness of my soul.

18407.text: ¶O Lord, by these things men live,/_and in all these is the life of my spirit./_Oh restore me to health and make me live!

18408.text: /Behold, it was for my welfare/_that I had great bitterness;/but in love you have delivered my life/_from the pit of destruction,/for you have cast all my sins/_behind your back.

18409.text: /For Sheol does not thank you;/_death does not praise you;/those who go down to the pit do not hope/_for your faithfulness.

18410.text: /The living, the living, he thanks you,/_as I do this day;/the father makes known to the children/_your faithfulness.

18411.text: ¶The Lord will save me,/_and we will play my music on stringed instruments/all the days of our lives,/_at the house of the Lord.

18412.text: ¶Now Isaiah had said, “Let them take a cake of figs and apply it to the boil, that he may recover.”

18413.text: Hezekiah also had said, “What is the sign that I shall go up to the house of the Lord?”

18414.text: §¶At that time Merodach‐baladan the son of Baladan, king of Babylon, sent envoys with letters and a present to Hezekiah, for he heard that he had been sick and had recovered.

18415.text: And Hezekiah welcomed them gladly. And he showed them his treasure house, the silver, the gold, the spices, the precious oil, his whole armory, all that was found in his storehouses. There was nothing in his house or in all his realm that Hezekiah did not show them.

18416.text: Then Isaiah the prophet came to King Hezekiah, and said to him, “What did these men say? And from where did they come to you?” Hezekiah said, “They have come to me from a far country, from Babylon.”

18417.text: He said, “What have they seen in your house?” Hezekiah answered, “They have seen all that is in my house. There is nothing in my storehouses that I did not show them.”

18418.text: ¶Then Isaiah said to Hezekiah, “Hear the word of the Lord of hosts:

18419.text: Behold, the days are coming, when all that is in your house, and that which your fathers have stored up till this day, shall be carried to Babylon. Nothing shall be left, says the Lord.

18420.text: And some of your own sons, who will come from you, whom you will father, shall be taken away, and they shall be eunuchs in the palace of the king of Babylon.”

18421.text: Then Hezekiah said to Isaiah, “The word of the Lord that you have spoken is good.” For he thought, “There will be peace and security in my days.”

18422.text: §¶Comfort, comfort my people, says your God.

18423.text: /Speak tenderly to Jerusalem,/_and cry to her/that her warfare is ended,/_that her iniquity is pardoned,/that she has received from the Lord’s hand/_double for all her sins.

18424.text: ¶A voice cries:/“In the wilderness prepare the way of the Lord;/_make straight in the desert a highway for our God.

18425.text: /Every valley shall be lifted up,/_and every mountain and hill be made low;/the uneven ground shall become level,/_and the rough places a plain.

18426.text: /And the glory of the Lord shall be revealed,/_and all flesh shall see it together,/_for the mouth of the Lord has spoken.”

18427.text: §¶A voice says, “Cry!”/_And I said, “What shall I cry?”/All flesh is grass,/_and all its beauty is like the flower of the field.

18428.text: /The grass withers, the flower fades/_when the breath of the Lord blows on it;/_surely the people are grass.

18429.text: /The grass withers, the flower fades,/_but the word of our God will stand forever.

18430.text: §¶Go on up to a high mountain,/_O Zion, herald of good news;/lift up your voice with strength,/_O Jerusalem, herald of good news;/_lift it up, fear not;/say to the cities of Judah,/_“Behold your God!”

18431.text: /Behold, the Lord God comes with might,/_and his arm rules for him;/behold, his reward is with him,/_and his recompense before him.

18432.text: /He will tend his flock like a shepherd;/_he will gather the lambs in his arms;/he will carry them in his bosom,/_and gently lead those that are with young.

18433.text: ¶Who has measured the waters in the hollow of his hand/_and marked off the heavens with a span,/enclosed the dust of the earth in a measure/_and weighed the mountains in scales/_and the hills in a balance?

18434.text: /Who has measured the Spirit of the Lord,/_or what man shows him his counsel?

18435.text: /Whom did he consult,/_and who made him understand?/Who taught him the path of justice,/_and taught him knowledge,/_and showed him the way of understanding?

18436.text: /Behold, the nations are like a drop from a bucket,/_and are accounted as the dust on the scales;/_behold, he takes up the coastlands like fine dust.

18437.text: /Lebanon would not suffice for fuel,/_nor are its beasts enough for a burnt offering.

18438.text: /All the nations are as nothing before him,/_they are accounted by him as less than nothing and emptiness.

18439.text: ¶To whom then will you liken God,/_or what likeness compare with him?

18440.text: /An idol! A craftsman casts it,/_and a goldsmith overlays it with gold/_and casts for it silver chains.

18441.text: /He who is too impoverished for an offering/_chooses wood that will not rot;/he seeks out a skillful craftsman/_to set up an idol that will not move.

18442.text: ¶Do you not know? Do you not hear?/_Has it not been told you from the beginning?/_Have you not understood from the foundations of the earth?

18443.text: /It is he who sits above the circle of the earth,/_and its inhabitants are like grasshoppers;/who stretches out the heavens like a curtain,/_and spreads them like a tent to dwell in;

18444.text: /who brings princes to nothing,/_and makes the rulers of the earth as emptiness.

18445.text: ¶Scarcely are they planted, scarcely sown,/_scarcely has their stem taken root in the earth,/when he blows on them, and they wither,/_and the tempest carries them off like stubble.

18446.text: ¶To whom then will you compare me,/_that I should be like him? says the Holy One.

18447.text: /Lift up your eyes on high and see:/_who created these?/He who brings out their host by number,/_calling them all by name,/by the greatness of his might,/_and because he is strong in power/_not one is missing.

18448.text: ¶Why do you say, O Jacob,/_and speak, O Israel,/“My way is hidden from the Lord,/_and my right is disregarded by my God”?

18449.text: /Have you not known? Have you not heard?/The Lord is the everlasting God,/_the Creator of the ends of the earth./He does not faint or grow weary;/_his understanding is unsearchable.

18450.text: /He gives power to the faint,/_and to him who has no might he increases strength.

18451.text: /Even youths shall faint and be weary,/_and young men shall fall exhausted;

18452.text: /but they who wait for the Lord shall renew their strength;/_they shall mount up with wings like eagles;/they shall run and not be weary;/_they shall walk and not faint.

18453.text: §¶Listen to me in silence, O coastlands;/_let the peoples renew their strength;/let them approach, then let them speak;/_let us together draw near for judgment.

18454.text: ¶Who stirred up one from the east/_whom victory meets at every step?/He gives up nations before him,/_so that he tramples kings underfoot;/he makes them like dust with his sword,/_like driven stubble with his bow.

18455.text: /He pursues them and passes on safely,/_by paths his feet have not trod.

18456.text: /Who has performed and done this,/_calling the generations from the beginning?/I, the Lord, the first,/_and with the last; I am he.

18457.text: ¶The coastlands have seen and are afraid;/_the ends of the earth tremble;/_they have drawn near and come.

18458.text: /Everyone helps his neighbor/_and says to his brother, “Be strong!”

18459.text: /The craftsman strengthens the goldsmith,/_and he who smooths with the hammer him who strikes the anvil,/saying of the soldering, “It is good”;/_and they strengthen it with nails so that it cannot be moved.

18460.text: ¶But you, Israel, my servant,/_Jacob, whom I have chosen,/_the offspring of Abraham, my friend;

18461.text: /you whom I took from the ends of the earth,/_and called from its farthest corners,/saying to you, “You are my servant,/_I have chosen you and not cast you off”;

18462.text: /fear not, for I am with you;/_be not dismayed, for I am your God;/I will strengthen you, I will help you,/_I will uphold you with my righteous right hand.

18463.text: ¶Behold, all who are incensed against you/_shall be put to shame and confounded;/those who strive against you/_shall be as nothing and shall perish.

18464.text: /You shall seek those who contend with you,/_but you shall not find them;/those who war against you/_shall be as nothing at all.

18465.text: /For I, the Lord your God,/_hold your right hand;/it is I who say to you, “Fear not,/_I am the one who helps you.”

18466.text: ¶Fear not, you worm Jacob,/_you men of Israel!/I am the one who helps you, declares the Lord;/_your Redeemer is the Holy One of Israel.

18467.text: /Behold, I make of you a threshing sledge,/_new, sharp, and having teeth;/you shall thresh the mountains and crush them,/_and you shall make the hills like chaff;

18468.text: /you shall winnow them, and the wind shall carry them away,/_and the tempest shall scatter them./And you shall rejoice in the Lord;/_in the Holy One of Israel you shall glory.

18469.text: ¶When the poor and needy seek water,/_and there is none,/_and their tongue is parched with thirst,/I the Lord will answer them;/_I the God of Israel will not forsake them.

18470.text: /I will open rivers on the bare heights,/_and fountains in the midst of the valleys./I will make the wilderness a pool of water,/_and the dry land springs of water.

18471.text: /I will put in the wilderness the cedar,/_the acacia, the myrtle, and the olive./I will set in the desert the cypress,/_the plane and the pine together,

18472.text: /that they may see and know,/_may consider and understand together,/that the hand of the Lord has done this,/_the Holy One of Israel has created it.

18473.text: §¶Set forth your case, says the Lord;/_bring your proofs, says the King of Jacob.

18474.text: /Let them bring them, and tell us/_what is to happen./Tell us the former things, what they are,/_that we may consider them,/that we may know their outcome;/_or declare to us the things to come.

18475.text: /Tell us what is to come hereafter,/_that we may know that you are gods;/do good, or do harm,/_that we may be dismayed and terrified.

18476.text: /Behold, you are nothing,/_and your work is less than nothing;/_an abomination is he who chooses you.

18477.text: ¶I stirred up one from the north, and he has come,/_from the rising of the sun, and he shall call upon my name;/he shall trample on rulers as on mortar,/_as the potter treads clay.

18478.text: /Who declared it from the beginning, that we might know,/_and beforehand, that we might say, “He is right”?/There was none who declared it, none who proclaimed,/_none who heard your words.

18479.text: /I was the first to say to Zion, “Behold, here they are!”/_and I give to Jerusalem a herald of good news.

18480.text: /But when I look, there is no one;/_among these there is no counselor/_who, when I ask, gives an answer.

18481.text: /Behold, they are all a delusion;/_their works are nothing;/_their metal images are empty wind.

18482.text: §¶Behold my servant, whom I uphold,/_my chosen, in whom my soul delights;/I have put my Spirit upon him;/_he will bring forth justice to the nations.

18483.text: /He will not cry aloud or lift up his voice,/_or make it heard in the street;

18484.text: /a bruised reed he will not break,/_and a faintly burning wick he will not quench;/_he will faithfully bring forth justice.

18485.text: /He will not grow faint or be discouraged/_till he has established justice in the earth;/_and the coastlands wait for his law.

18486.text: ¶Thus says God, the Lord,/_who created the heavens and stretched them out,/_who spread out the earth and what comes from it,/who gives breath to the people on it/_and spirit to those who walk in it:

18487.text: /“I am the Lord; I have called you in righteousness;/_I will take you by the hand and keep you;/I will give you as a covenant for the people,/_a light for the nations,

18488.text: /_to open the eyes that are blind,/to bring out the prisoners from the dungeon,/_from the prison those who sit in darkness.

18489.text: /I am the Lord; that is my name;/_my glory I give to no other,/_nor my praise to carved idols.

18490.text: /Behold, the former things have come to pass,/_and new things I now declare;/before they spring forth/_I tell you of them.”

18491.text: §¶Sing to the Lord a new song,/_his praise from the end of the earth,/you who go down to the sea, and all that fills it,/_the coastlands and their inhabitants.

18492.text: /Let the desert and its cities lift up their voice,/_the villages that Kedar inhabits;/let the habitants of Sela sing for joy,/_let them shout from the top of the mountains.

18493.text: /Let them give glory to the Lord,/_and declare his praise in the coastlands.

18494.text: /The Lord goes out like a mighty man,/_like a man of war he stirs up his zeal;/he cries out, he shouts aloud,/_he shows himself mighty against his foes.

18495.text: ¶For a long time I have held my peace;/_I have kept still and restrained myself;/now I will cry out like a woman in labor;/_I will gasp and pant.

18496.text: /I will lay waste mountains and hills,/_and dry up all their vegetation;/I will turn the rivers into islands,/_and dry up the pools.

18497.text: /And I will lead the blind/_in a way that they do not know,/in paths that they have not known/_I will guide them./I will turn the darkness before them into light,/_the rough places into level ground./These are the things I do,/_and I do not forsake them.

18498.text: /They are turned back and utterly put to shame,/_who trust in carved idols,/who say to metal images,/_“You are our gods.”

18499.text: §¶Hear, you deaf,/_and look, you blind, that you may see!

18500.text: /Who is blind but my servant,/_or deaf as my messenger whom I send?/Who is blind as my dedicated one,/_or blind as the servant of the Lord?

18501.text: /He sees many things, but does not observe them;/_his ears are open, but he does not hear.

18502.text: /The Lord was pleased, for his righteousness’ sake,/_to magnify his law and make it glorious.

18503.text: /But this is a people plundered and looted;/_they are all of them trapped in holes/_and hidden in prisons;/they have become plunder with none to rescue,/_spoil with none to say, “Restore!”

18504.text: /Who among you will give ear to this,/_will attend and listen for the time to come?

18505.text: /Who gave up Jacob to the looter,/_and Israel to the plunderers?/Was it not the Lord, against whom we have sinned,/_in whose ways they would not walk,/_and whose law they would not obey?

18506.text: /So he poured on him the heat of his anger/_and the might of battle;/it set him on fire all around, but he did not understand;/_it burned him up, but he did not take it to heart.

18507.text: §¶But now thus says the Lord,/he who created you, O Jacob,/_he who formed you, O Israel:/“Fear not, for I have redeemed you;/_I have called you by name, you are mine.

18508.text: /When you pass through the waters, I will be with you;/_and through the rivers, they shall not overwhelm you;/when you walk through fire you shall not be burned,/_and the flame shall not consume you.

18509.text: /For I am the Lord your God,/_the Holy One of Israel, your Savior./I give Egypt as your ransom,/_Cush and Seba in exchange for you.

18510.text: /Because you are precious in my eyes,/_and honored, and I love you,/I give men in return for you,/_peoples in exchange for your life.

18511.text: /Fear not, for I am with you;/_I will bring your offspring from the east,/_and from the west I will gather you.

18512.text: /I will say to the north, Give up,/_and to the south, Do not withhold;/bring my sons from afar/_and my daughters from the end of the earth,

18513.text: /everyone who is called by my name,/_whom I created for my glory,/_whom I formed and made.”

18514.text: ¶Bring out the people who are blind, yet have eyes,/_who are deaf, yet have ears!

18515.text: /All the nations gather together,/_and the peoples assemble./Who among them can declare this,/_and show us the former things?/Let them bring their witnesses to prove them right,/_and let them hear and say, It is true.

18516.text: /“You are my witnesses,” declares the Lord,/_“and my servant whom I have chosen,/that you may know and believe me/_and understand that I am he./Before me no god was formed,/_nor shall there be any after me.

18517.text: /I, I am the Lord,/_and besides me there is no savior.

18518.text: /I declared and saved and proclaimed,/_when there was no strange god among you;/_and you are my witnesses,” declares the Lord, “and I am God.

18519.text: /Also henceforth I am he;/_there is none who can deliver from my hand;/_I work, and who can turn it back?”

18520.text: ¶Thus says the Lord,/_your Redeemer, the Holy One of Israel:/“For your sake I send to Babylon/_and bring them all down as fugitives,/_even the Chaldeans, in the ships in which they rejoice.

18521.text: /I am the Lord, your Holy One,/_the Creator of Israel, your King.”

18522.text: ¶Thus says the Lord,/_who makes a way in the sea,/_a path in the mighty waters,

18523.text: /who brings forth chariot and horse,/_army and warrior;/they lie down, they cannot rise,/_they are extinguished, quenched like a wick:

18524.text: /“Remember not the former things,/_nor consider the things of old.

18525.text: /Behold, I am doing a new thing;/_now it springs forth, do you not perceive it?/I will make a way in the wilderness/_and rivers in the desert.

18526.text: /The wild beasts will honor me,/_the jackals and the ostriches,/for I give water in the wilderness,/_rivers in the desert,/to give drink to my chosen people,

18527.text: /_the people whom I formed for myself/that they might declare my praise.

18528.text: ¶“Yet you did not call upon me, O Jacob;/_but you have been weary of me, O Israel!

18529.text: /You have not brought me your sheep for burnt offerings,/_or honored me with your sacrifices./I have not burdened you with offerings,/_or wearied you with frankincense.

18530.text: /You have not bought me sweet cane with money,/_or satisfied me with the fat of your sacrifices./But you have burdened me with your sins;/_you have wearied me with your iniquities.

18531.text: ¶“I, I am he/_who blots out your transgressions for my own sake,/_and I will not remember your sins.

18532.text: /Put me in remembrance; let us argue together;/_set forth your case, that you may be proved right.

18533.text: /Your first father sinned,/_and your mediators transgressed against me.

18534.text: /Therefore I will profane the princes of the sanctuary,/_and deliver Jacob to utter destruction/_and Israel to reviling.

18535.text: §¶“But now hear, O Jacob my servant,/_Israel whom I have chosen!

18536.text: /Thus says the Lord who made you,/_who formed you from the womb and will help you:/Fear not, O Jacob my servant,/_Jeshurun whom I have chosen.

18537.text: /For I will pour water on the thirsty land,/_and streams on the dry ground;/I will pour my Spirit upon your offspring,/_and my blessing on your descendants.

18538.text: /They shall spring up among the grass/_like willows by flowing streams.

18539.text: /This one will say, ‘I am the Lord’s,’/_another will call on the name of Jacob,/and another will write on his hand, ‘The Lord’s,’/_and name himself by the name of Israel.”

18540.text: §¶Thus says the Lord, the King of Israel/_and his Redeemer, the Lord of hosts:/“I am the first and I am the last;/_besides me there is no god.

18541.text: /Who is like me? Let him proclaim it./_Let him declare and set it before me,/since I appointed an ancient people./_Let them declare what is to come, and what will happen.

18542.text: /Fear not, nor be afraid;/_have I not told you from of old and declared it?/_And you are my witnesses!/Is there a God besides me?/_There is no Rock; I know not any.”

18543.text: §¶All who fashion idols are nothing, and the things they delight in do not profit. Their witnesses neither see nor know, that they may be put to shame.

18544.text: Who fashions a god or casts an idol that is profitable for nothing?

18545.text: Behold, all his companions shall be put to shame, and the craftsmen are only human. Let them all assemble, let them stand forth. They shall be terrified; they shall be put to shame together.

18546.text: ¶The ironsmith takes a cutting tool and works it over the coals. He fashions it with hammers and works it with his strong arm. He becomes hungry, and his strength fails; he drinks no water and is faint.

18547.text: The carpenter stretches a line; he marks it out with a pencil. He shapes it with planes and marks it with a compass. He shapes it into the figure of a man, with the beauty of a man, to dwell in a house.

18548.text: He cuts down cedars, or he chooses a cypress tree or an oak and lets it grow strong among the trees of the forest. He plants a cedar and the rain nourishes it.

18549.text: Then it becomes fuel for a man. He takes a part of it and warms himself; he kindles a fire and bakes bread. Also he makes a god and worships it; he makes it an idol and falls down before it.

18550.text: Half of it he burns in the fire. Over the half he eats meat; he roasts it and is satisfied. Also he warms himself and says, “Aha, I am warm, I have seen the fire!”

18551.text: And the rest of it he makes into a god, his idol, and falls down to it and worships it. He prays to it and says, “Deliver me, for you are my god!”

18552.text: ¶They know not, nor do they discern, for he has shut their eyes, so that they cannot see, and their hearts, so that they cannot understand.

18553.text: No one considers, nor is there knowledge or discernment to say, “Half of it I burned in the fire; I also baked bread on its coals; I roasted meat and have eaten. And shall I make the rest of it an abomination? Shall I fall down before a block of wood?”

18554.text: He feeds on ashes; a deluded heart has led him astray, and he cannot deliver himself or say, “Is there not a lie in my right hand?”

18555.text: §¶Remember these things, O Jacob,/_and Israel, for you are my servant;/I formed you; you are my servant;/_O Israel, you will not be forgotten by me.

18556.text: /I have blotted out your transgressions like a cloud/_and your sins like mist;/return to me, for I have redeemed you.

18557.text: ¶Sing, O heavens, for the Lord has done it;/_shout, O depths of the earth;/break forth into singing, O mountains,/_O forest, and every tree in it!/For the Lord has redeemed Jacob,/_and will be glorified in Israel.

18558.text: ¶Thus says the Lord, your Redeemer,/_who formed you from the womb:/“I am the Lord, who made all things,/_who alone stretched out the heavens,/_who spread out the earth by myself,

18559.text: /who frustrates the signs of liars/_and makes fools of diviners,/who turns wise men back/_and makes their knowledge foolish,

18560.text: /who confirms the word of his servant/_and fulfills the counsel of his messengers,/who says of Jerusalem, ‘She shall be inhabited,’/_and of the cities of Judah, ‘They shall be built,/_and I will raise up their ruins’;

18561.text: /who says to the deep, ‘Be dry;/_I will dry up your rivers’;

18562.text: /who says of Cyrus, ‘He is my shepherd,/_and he shall fulfill all my purpose’;/saying of Jerusalem, ‘She shall be built,’/_and of the temple, ‘Your foundation shall be laid.’”

18563.text: §¶Thus says the Lord to his anointed, to Cyrus,/_whose right hand I have grasped,/to subdue nations before him/_and to loose the belts of kings,/to open doors before him/_that gates may not be closed:

18564.text: /“I will go before you/_and level the exalted places,/I will break in pieces the doors of bronze/_and cut through the bars of iron,

18565.text: /I will give you the treasures of darkness/_and the hoards in secret places,/that you may know that it is I, the Lord,/_the God of Israel, who call you by your name.

18566.text: /For the sake of my servant Jacob,/_and Israel my chosen,/I call you by your name,/_I name you, though you do not know me.

18567.text: /I am the Lord, and there is no other,/_besides me there is no God;/_I equip you, though you do not know me,

18568.text: /that people may know, from the rising of the sun/_and from the west, that there is none besides me;/_I am the Lord, and there is no other.

18569.text: /I form light and create darkness,/_I make well‐being and create calamity,/_I am the Lord, who does all these things.

18570.text: ¶“Shower, O heavens, from above,/_and let the clouds rain down righteousness;/let the earth open, that salvation and righteousness may bear fruit;/_let the earth cause them both to sprout;/_I the Lord have created it.

18571.text: ¶“Woe to him who strives with him who formed him,/_a pot among earthen pots!/Does the clay say to him who forms it, ‘What are you making?’/_or ‘Your work has no handles’?

18572.text: /Woe to him who says to a father, ‘What are you begetting?’/_or to a woman, ‘With what are you in labor?’”

18573.text: ¶Thus says the Lord,/_the Holy One of Israel, and the one who formed him:/“Ask me of things to come;/_will you command me concerning my children and the work of my hands?

18574.text: /I made the earth/_and created man on it;/it was my hands that stretched out the heavens,/_and I commanded all their host.

18575.text: /I have stirred him up in righteousness,/_and I will make all his ways level;/he shall build my city/_and set my exiles free,/not for price or reward,”/_says the Lord of hosts.

18576.text: §¶Thus says the Lord:/“The wealth of Egypt and the merchandise of Cush,/_and the Sabeans, men of stature,/shall come over to you and be yours;/_they shall follow you;/_they shall come over in chains and bow down to you./They will plead with you, saying:/_‘Surely God is in you, and there is no other,/_no god besides him.’”

18577.text: ¶Truly, you are a God who hides himself,/_O God of Israel, the Savior.

18578.text: /All of them are put to shame and confounded;/_the makers of idols go in confusion together.

18579.text: /But Israel is saved by the Lord/_with everlasting salvation;/you shall not be put to shame or confounded/_to all eternity.

18580.text: ¶For thus says the Lord,/who created the heavens/_(he is God!),/who formed the earth and made it/_(he established it;/he did not create it empty,/_he formed it to be inhabited!):/“I am the Lord, and there is no other.

18581.text: /I did not speak in secret,/_in a land of darkness;/I did not say to the offspring of Jacob,/_‘Seek me in vain.’/I the Lord speak the truth;/_I declare what is right.

18582.text: ¶“Assemble yourselves and come;/_draw near together,/_you survivors of the nations!/They have no knowledge/_who carry about their wooden idols,/and keep on praying to a god/_that cannot save.

18583.text: /Declare and present your case;/_let them take counsel together!/Who told this long ago?/_Who declared it of old?/Was it not I, the Lord?/_And there is no other god besides me,/a righteous God and a Savior;/_there is none besides me.

18584.text: ¶“Turn to me and be saved,/_all the ends of the earth!/_For I am God, and there is no other.

18585.text: /By myself I have sworn;/_from my mouth has gone out in righteousness/_a word that shall not return:/‘To me every knee shall bow,/_every tongue shall swear allegiance.’

18586.text: ¶“Only in the Lord, it shall be said of me,/_are righteousness and strength;/to him shall come and be ashamed/_all who were incensed against him.

18587.text: /In the Lord all the offspring of Israel/_shall be justified and shall glory.”

18588.text: §¶Bel bows down; Nebo stoops;/_their idols are on beasts and livestock;/these things you carry are borne/_as burdens on weary beasts.

18589.text: /They stoop; they bow down together;/_they cannot save the burden,/_but themselves go into captivity.

18590.text: ¶“Listen to me, O house of Jacob,/_all the remnant of the house of Israel,/who have been borne by me from before your birth,/_carried from the womb;

18591.text: /even to your old age I am he,/_and to gray hairs I will carry you./I have made, and I will bear;/_I will carry and will save.

18592.text: ¶“To whom will you liken me and make me equal,/_and compare me, that we may be alike?

18593.text: /Those who lavish gold from the purse,/_and weigh out silver in the scales,/hire a goldsmith, and he makes it into a god;/_then they fall down and worship!

18594.text: /They lift it to their shoulders, they carry it,/_they set it in its place, and it stands there;/_it cannot move from its place./If one cries to it, it does not answer/_or save him from his trouble.

18595.text: ¶“Remember this and stand firm,/_recall it to mind, you transgressors,

18596.text: /_remember the former things of old;/for I am God, and there is no other;/_I am God, and there is none like me,

18597.text: /declaring the end from the beginning/_and from ancient times things not yet done,/saying, ‘My counsel shall stand,/_and I will accomplish all my purpose,’

18598.text: /calling a bird of prey from the east,/_the man of my counsel from a far country./I have spoken, and I will bring it to pass;/_I have purposed, and I will do it.

18599.text: ¶“Listen to me, you stubborn of heart,/_you who are far from righteousness:

18600.text: /I bring near my righteousness; it is not far off,/_and my salvation will not delay;/I will put salvation in Zion,/_for Israel my glory.”

18601.text: §¶Come down and sit in the dust,/_O virgin daughter of Babylon;/sit on the ground without a throne,/_O daughter of the Chaldeans!/For you shall no more be called/_tender and delicate.

18602.text: /Take the millstones and grind flour,/_put off your veil,/strip off your robe, uncover your legs,/_pass through the rivers.

18603.text: /Your nakedness shall be uncovered,/_and your disgrace shall be seen./I will take vengeance,/_and I will spare no one.

18604.text: /Our Redeemer—the Lord of hosts is his name—/_is the Holy One of Israel.

18605.text: ¶Sit in silence, and go into darkness,/_O daughter of the Chaldeans;/for you shall no more be called/_the mistress of kingdoms.

18606.text: /I was angry with my people;/_I profaned my heritage;/I gave them into your hand;/_you showed them no mercy;/on the aged you made your yoke exceedingly heavy.

18607.text: /You said, “I shall be mistress forever,”/_so that you did not lay these things to heart/_or remember their end.

18608.text: ¶Now therefore hear this, you lover of pleasures,/_who sit securely,/who say in your heart,/_“I am, and there is no one besides me;/I shall not sit as a widow/_or know the loss of children”:

18609.text: /These two things shall come to you/_in a moment, in one day;/the loss of children and widowhood/_shall come upon you in full measure,/in spite of your many sorceries/_and the great power of your enchantments.

18610.text: ¶You felt secure in your wickedness,/_you said, “No one sees me”;/your wisdom and your knowledge led you astray,/and you said in your heart,/_“I am, and there is no one besides me.”

18611.text: /But evil shall come upon you,/_which you will not know how to charm away;/disaster shall fall upon you,/_for which you will not be able to atone;/and ruin shall come upon you suddenly,/_of which you know nothing.

18612.text: ¶Stand fast in your enchantments/_and your many sorceries,/_with which you have labored from your youth;/perhaps you may be able to succeed;/_perhaps you may inspire terror.

18613.text: /You are wearied with your many counsels;/_let them stand forth and save you,/those who divide the heavens,/_who gaze at the stars,/who at the new moons make known/_what shall come upon you.

18614.text: ¶Behold, they are like stubble;/_the fire consumes them;/they cannot deliver themselves/_from the power of the flame./No coal for warming oneself is this,/_no fire to sit before!

18615.text: /Such to you are those with whom you have labored,/_who have done business with you from your youth;/they wander about, each in his own direction;/_there is no one to save you.

18616.text: §¶Hear this, O house of Jacob,/_who are called by the name of Israel,/_and who came from the waters of Judah,/who swear by the name of the Lord/_and confess the God of Israel,/_but not in truth or right.

18617.text: /For they call themselves after the holy city,/_and stay themselves on the God of Israel;/_the Lord of hosts is his name.

18618.text: ¶“The former things I declared of old;/_they went out from my mouth, and I announced them;/_then suddenly I did them, and they came to pass.

18619.text: /Because I know that you are obstinate,/_and your neck is an iron sinew/_and your forehead brass,

18620.text: /I declared them to you from of old,/_before they came to pass I announced them to you,/lest you should say, ‘My idol did them,/_my carved image and my metal image commanded them.’

18621.text: ¶“You have heard; now see all this;/_and will you not declare it?/From this time forth I announce to you new things,/_hidden things that you have not known.

18622.text: /They are created now, not long ago;/_before today you have never heard of them,/_lest you should say, ‘Behold, I knew them.’

18623.text: /You have never heard, you have never known,/_from of old your ear has not been opened./For I knew that you would surely deal treacherously,/_and that from before birth you were called a rebel.

18624.text: ¶“For my name’s sake I defer my anger,/_for the sake of my praise I restrain it for you,/_that I may not cut you off.

18625.text: /Behold, I have refined you, but not as silver;/_I have tried you in the furnace of affliction.

18626.text: /For my own sake, for my own sake, I do it,/_for how should my name be profaned?/_My glory I will not give to another.

18627.text: §¶“Listen to me, O Jacob,/_and Israel, whom I called!/I am he; I am the first,/_and I am the last.

18628.text: /My hand laid the foundation of the earth,/_and my right hand spread out the heavens;/when I call to them,/_they stand forth together.

18629.text: ¶“Assemble, all of you, and listen!/_Who among them has declared these things?/The Lord loves him;/_he shall perform his purpose on Babylon,/_and his arm shall be against the Chaldeans.

18630.text: /I, even I, have spoken and called him;/_I have brought him, and he will prosper in his way.

18631.text: /Draw near to me, hear this:/_from the beginning I have not spoken in secret,/_from the time it came to be I have been there.”/And now the Lord God has sent me, and his Spirit.

18632.text: ¶Thus says the Lord,/_your Redeemer, the Holy One of Israel:/“I am the Lord your God,/_who teaches you to profit,/_who leads you in the way you should go.

18633.text: /Oh that you had paid attention to my commandments!/_Then your peace would have been like a river,/_and your righteousness like the waves of the sea;

18634.text: /your offspring would have been like the sand,/_and your descendants like its grains;/their name would never be cut off/_or destroyed from before me.”

18635.text: ¶Go out from Babylon, flee from Chaldea,/_declare this with a shout of joy, proclaim it,/send it out to the end of the earth;/_say, “The Lord has redeemed his servant Jacob!”

18636.text: /They did not thirst when he led them through the deserts;/_he made water flow for them from the rock;/_he split the rock and the water gushed out.

18637.text: ¶“There is no peace,” says the Lord, “for the wicked.”

18638.text: §¶Listen to me, O coastlands,/_and give attention, you peoples from afar./The Lord called me from the womb,/_from the body of my mother he named my name.

18639.text: /He made my mouth like a sharp sword;/_in the shadow of his hand he hid me;/he made me a polished arrow;/_in his quiver he hid me away.

18640.text: /And he said to me, “You are my servant,/_Israel, in whom I will be glorified.”

18641.text: /But I said, “I have labored in vain;/_I have spent my strength for nothing and vanity;/yet surely my right is with the Lord,/_and my recompense with my God.”

18642.text: ¶And now the Lord says,/_he who formed me from the womb to be his servant,/to bring Jacob back to him;/_and that Israel might be gathered to him—/for I am honored in the eyes of the Lord,/_and my God has become my strength—

18643.text: /he says:/“It is too light a thing that you should be my servant/_to raise up the tribes of Jacob/_and to bring back the preserved of Israel;/I will make you as a light for the nations,/_that my salvation may reach to the end of the earth.”

18644.text: ¶Thus says the Lord,/_the Redeemer of Israel and his Holy One,/to one deeply despised, abhorred by the nation,/_the servant of rulers:/“Kings shall see and arise;/_princes, and they shall prostrate themselves;/because of the Lord, who is faithful,/_the Holy One of Israel, who has chosen you.”

18645.text: §¶Thus says the Lord:/“In a time of favor I have answered you;/_in a day of salvation I have helped you;/I will keep you and give you/_as a covenant to the people,/to establish the land,/_to apportion the desolate heritages,

18646.text: /saying to the prisoners, ‘Come out,’/_to those who are in darkness, ‘Appear.’/They shall feed along the ways;/_on all bare heights shall be their pasture;

18647.text: /they shall not hunger or thirst,/_neither scorching wind nor sun shall strike them,/for he who has pity on them will lead them,/_and by springs of water will guide them.

18648.text: /And I will make all my mountains a road,/_and my highways shall be raised up.

18649.text: /Behold, these shall come from afar,/_and behold, these from the north and from the west,/_and these from the land of Syene.”

18650.text: ¶Sing for joy, O heavens, and exult, O earth;/_break forth, O mountains, into singing!/For the Lord has comforted his people/_and will have compassion on his afflicted.

18651.text: ¶But Zion said, “The Lord has forsaken me;/_my Lord has forgotten me.”

18652.text: ¶“Can a woman forget her nursing child,/_that she should have no compassion on the son of her womb?/Even these may forget,/_yet I will not forget you.

18653.text: /Behold, I have engraved you on the palms of my hands;/_your walls are continually before me.

18654.text: /Your builders make haste;/_your destroyers and those who laid you waste go out from you.

18655.text: /Lift up your eyes around and see;/_they all gather, they come to you./As I live, declares the Lord,/_you shall put them all on as an ornament;/_you shall bind them on as a bride does.

18656.text: ¶“Surely your waste and your desolate places/_and your devastated land—/surely now you will be too narrow for your inhabitants,/_and those who swallowed you up will be far away.

18657.text: /The children of your bereavement/_will yet say in your ears:/‘The place is too narrow for me;/_make room for me to dwell in.’

18658.text: /Then you will say in your heart:/_‘Who has borne me these?/I was bereaved and barren,/_exiled and put away,/_but who has brought up these?/Behold, I was left alone;/_from where have these come?’”

18659.text: ¶Thus says the Lord God:/“Behold, I will lift up my hand to the nations,/_and raise my signal to the peoples;/and they shall bring your sons in their arms,/_and your daughters shall be carried on their shoulders.

18660.text: /Kings shall be your foster fathers,/_and their queens your nursing mothers./With their faces to the ground they shall bow down to you,/_and lick the dust of your feet./Then you will know that I am the Lord;/_those who wait for me shall not be put to shame.”

18661.text: ¶Can the prey be taken from the mighty,/_or the captives of a tyrant be rescued?

18662.text: /For thus says the Lord:/“Even the captives of the mighty shall be taken,/_and the prey of the tyrant be rescued,/for I will contend with those who contend with you,/_and I will save your children.

18663.text: /I will make your oppressors eat their own flesh,/_and they shall be drunk with their own blood as with wine./Then all flesh shall know/_that I am the Lord your Savior,/_and your Redeemer, the Mighty One of Jacob.”

18664.text: §¶Thus says the Lord:/“Where is your mother’s certificate of divorce,/_with which I sent her away?/Or which of my creditors is it/_to whom I have sold you?/Behold, for your iniquities you were sold,/_and for your transgressions your mother was sent away.

18665.text: /Why, when I came, was there no man;/_why, when I called, was there no one to answer?/Is my hand shortened, that it cannot redeem?/_Or have I no power to deliver?/Behold, by my rebuke I dry up the sea,/_I make the rivers a desert;/their fish stink for lack of water/_and die of thirst.

18666.text: /I clothe the heavens with blackness/_and make sackcloth their covering.”

18667.text: ¶The Lord God has given me/_the tongue of those who are taught,/that I may know how to sustain with a word/_him who is weary./Morning by morning he awakens;/_he awakens my ear/_to hear as those who are taught.

18668.text: /The Lord God has opened my ear,/_and I was not rebellious;/_I turned not backward.

18669.text: /I gave my back to those who strike,/_and my cheeks to those who pull out the beard;/I hid not my face/_from disgrace and spitting.

18670.text: ¶But the Lord God helps me;/_therefore I have not been disgraced;/therefore I have set my face like a flint,/_and I know that I shall not be put to shame.

18671.text: /_He who vindicates me is near./Who will contend with me?/_Let us stand up together./Who is my adversary?/_Let him come near to me.

18672.text: /Behold, the Lord God helps me;/_who will declare me guilty?/Behold, all of them will wear out like a garment;/_the moth will eat them up.

18673.text: ¶Who among you fears the Lord/_and obeys the voice of his servant?/Let him who walks in darkness/_and has no light/trust in the name of the Lord/_and rely on his God.

18674.text: /Behold, all you who kindle a fire,/_who equip yourselves with burning torches!/Walk by the light of your fire,/_and by the torches that you have kindled!/This you have from my hand:/_you shall lie down in torment.

18675.text: §¶“Listen to me, you who pursue righteousness,/_you who seek the Lord:/look to the rock from which you were hewn,/_and to the quarry from which you were dug.

18676.text: /Look to Abraham your father/_and to Sarah who bore you;/for he was but one when I called him,/_that I might bless him and multiply him.

18677.text: /For the Lord comforts Zion;/_he comforts all her waste places/and makes her wilderness like Eden,/_her desert like the garden of the Lord;/joy and gladness will be found in her,/_thanksgiving and the voice of song.

18678.text: ¶“Give attention to me, my people,/_and give ear to me, my nation;/for a law will go out from me,/_and I will set my justice for a light to the peoples.

18679.text: /My righteousness draws near,/_my salvation has gone out,/_and my arms will judge the peoples;/the coastlands hope for me,/_and for my arm they wait.

18680.text: /Lift up your eyes to the heavens,/_and look at the earth beneath;/for the heavens vanish like smoke,/_the earth will wear out like a garment,/_and they who dwell in it will die in like manner;/but my salvation will be forever,/_and my righteousness will never be dismayed.

18681.text: ¶“Listen to me, you who know righteousness,/_the people in whose heart is my law;/fear not the reproach of man,/_nor be dismayed at their revilings.

18682.text: /For the moth will eat them up like a garment,/_and the worm will eat them like wool;/but my righteousness will be forever,/_and my salvation to all generations.”

18683.text: ¶Awake, awake, put on strength,/_O arm of the Lord;/awake, as in days of old,/_the generations of long ago./Was it not you who cut Rahab in pieces,/_who pierced the dragon?

18684.text: /Was it not you who dried up the sea,/_the waters of the great deep,/who made the depths of the sea a way/_for the redeemed to pass over?

18685.text: /And the ransomed of the Lord shall return/_and come to Zion with singing;/everlasting joy shall be upon their heads;/_they shall obtain gladness and joy,/_and sorrow and sighing shall flee away.

18686.text: ¶“I, I am he who comforts you;/_who are you that you are afraid of man who dies,/_of the son of man who is made like grass,

18687.text: /and have forgotten the Lord, your Maker,/_who stretched out the heavens/_and laid the foundations of the earth,/and you fear continually all the day/_because of the wrath of the oppressor,/when he sets himself to destroy?/_And where is the wrath of the oppressor?

18688.text: /He who is bowed down shall speedily be released;/_he shall not die and go down to the pit,/_neither shall his bread be lacking.

18689.text: /I am the Lord your God,/_who stirs up the sea so that its waves roar—/_the Lord of hosts is his name.

18690.text: /And I have put my words in your mouth/_and covered you in the shadow of my hand,/establishing the heavens/_and laying the foundations of the earth,/_and saying to Zion, ‘You are my people.’”

18691.text: ¶Wake yourself, wake yourself,/_stand up, O Jerusalem,/you who have drunk from the hand of the Lord/_the cup of his wrath,/who have drunk to the dregs/_the bowl, the cup of staggering.
